intro: Amaracarpus subcaudatus, commonly known as the slender amara, is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its fibrous roots and showy flowers. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of South America, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. The plant features palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its flowers are typically pink or red, arranged in clusters. It produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, oblong seeds. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
